Adipurush, if one remembers, was supposed to be an modern adaptation of Ramayan and hence the makers chose to have a free run with the creative liberties in this film and it all went wrong .

Adipurush itself starts from the middle of Ramayana where lord Ram was sent to the jungles for 14 years exile . Hence the film doesn't have any build up to any character.

First, the characters itself have no introduction whatsoever. Makers assume since we know Ramayana, so no need to introduce anyone properly. Lord Ram is just introduced through some pictures in the opening credit while laxman and Sita ma have even further lower introduction. Honestly saying if one didn't tell you that Sunny Singh is laxman, you probably won't know. Jatayu pops up randomly and gets to poorest adieu . It's almost as if Lord Ram doesn't even know who Jatayu is. Bali , the brother of Sugreev, has absolutely no introduction.

Next, the setting. If it's a modern adaptation of Ramayana, then why is the Lord Ram side shown to be taken straight from Ramayana but Lanka and it's people especially Raavan are shown as people of some Azguard (Thor) ? Clearly there is inconsistency . If you remember the original Ramayana, both Ram and Raavan side had almost similar kind of dresses with kings wearing king like dresses etc. Here, both sides wear dresses belonging to opposite poles.

Next, the execution. It's horrendous. Bali and Sugreev's fight is the worst looking one which gets over in no time without any introduction to Bali. As they fight, you can't even understand who is Bali and who is Sugreev. The part where Sita gets kidnapped by the Sadhu is not accurate. The Sadhu i believe never gave evil smiles . Jatayu's adieu is just ignored. In the earlier Ramayana, Jatayu has a heartfelt conversation with lord Ram in his arms before dying but here, Jatayu is just treated like a random bird. Last but not the least, everything on the lankan side is so poorly executed. Lord Hanuman burns Lanka with his tail but it barely burns, just random explosions here and there that's it.

Next, I want to talk about Indrajith and Vibhishan. My god what kind of portrayal is this? Indrajit looks like a party animal from some Noida club and he possesses powers of Flash !! The level of creative liberties they took!! Vibhishan is so hard to believe he's vibhishan as he doesn't act like him only . They all got weird tattoos on their body especially indrajith . Itna bhi modern nahi karna tha !!

VFX and dialogues. Let's not talk about it you already know how it is. The final war sequence also looks so cartoonish that it sucks the essence out of it.

Let's talk about Raavan played by Saif. He does try very hard to make Raavan look menacing. His character is even given a terrifying bgm . However, the rest things of his looks so weird. His 10 heads rendered VFX looks hilarious at best. His hairstyle is again Noida Gurugram style. He feeds non veg to his dragon vehicle (why is non veg shown in this film at first place?). All these creative choices just don't fit Raavan. The makers have just played around with the Lanka side while fearfully avoiding any creative changes on Ram side .

Songs are good as well as the BGM. That's the only reason I gave this film 2 stars.

Prabhas as lord Ram should never have been there. He's just angry faced , barely smiles and has no expressions at all. His body is an entire VFX render throughout.

Overall, i thought KBKJ was the worst film this year but Adipurush beats it by a mile solely because it has ruined an epic saga so close to all Hindus. Adipurush just shows a part of the entire Ramayana that too with little to no detailing with its running time being 3 hrs and back in 1992, the Yugo Sako version showed all details and the entire tale of Ram in under 2hrs 50 mins. It clearly shows the quality difference of the makers .

Adipurush, directed by Om Raut, is an epic retelling of the revered Hindu mythological tale, the Ramayan. With its perfect casting, melodic music, incredible graphics, and breathtaking war sequences, the film successfully captivated me. Adipurush showcases the journey of Lord Ram, portrayed impeccably by Prabhas, and highlights his heroic exploits in the battle against the formidable Ravan.

One of the film's standout aspects is the perfect casting of Prabhas as Lord Ram. His demeanour exudes the noble qualities and righteousness that the character demands. Prabhas's screen presence and dedication to his role elevate the heroism of Sri Ram, making his character truly engaging and inspiring.

The melodic music of Adipurush adds depth and emotion to the storytelling. The film's soundtrack beautifully complements the narrative, enhancing the audience's connection with the characters and their journey. The songs and background score resonate well with the mythological theme, providing a rich and immersive experience.

Indian makers have left no stone unturned in creating incredible graphics and visually stunning war sequences. The grandeur and attention to detail in these scenes are truly commendable. The battles are choreographed and executed with precision, making them a spectacle to behold. The Indian film industry showcases its technical prowess through the impressive visual effects, which enhance the mythological elements of the story.

Adipurush does justice to the important episodes of the Ramayan, whether it's the encounter with Jatayuvu, the meeting with Shabari, or the iconic scene of Hanuman burning Lanka. Each episode is beautifully shot, capturing the essence and significance of these moments. The attention to detail and the portrayal of these episodes add depth and meaning to the overall narrative.

The film presents a strong portrayal of Ravan, who serves as the antagonist to Sri Ram's heroism. The character of Ravan is depicted with depth and complexity, showcasing his power and intelligence. This adds to the overall conflict and raises the stakes for Lord Ram, creating a compelling dynamic between the two characters.

However, one of the drawbacks of Adipurush is that most of the sequences are shot in dark settings. While this might add to the intensity and mood of certain scenes, it results in a lack of colorful skies, vibrant flowers, and visually appealing clothing. This absence of vivid colors can make the film feel somewhat monotonous visually, especially considering the grandeur and beauty associated with the Ramayan. Most negative reviews are nit picking, ignoring the larger picture.

In conclusion, Adipurush is a visually stunning and emotionally captivating retelling of the Ramayan. Prabhas delivers a remarkable performance as Lord Ram, and the film's music, graphics, and war sequences leave a lasting impact. While the dark settings might be a drawback for some viewers, the overall experience of the film is engrossing, and it successfully brings to life the epic tale of good versus evil. I am no big devotee of Sri Ram but this elevated my reverence for him. I am proud that an Indian has made such an epic film. Adipurush is a must-watch for fans of mythology and epic storytelling.

Director Om Raut's highly anticipated film "Adipurush" promised to be a grand retelling of the epic Ramayan with a star-studded cast including Prabhas, Kriti Sanon, Saif Ali Khan, and Devdutta Nage. This lackluster visual quality is particularly disappointing considering the film's large budget and the potential for stunning visuals within the context of the Ramayan.

Another significant flaw lies in how the film handles the sacred story of the Ramayan. Kriti Sanon's portrayal of Sita lacks depth and fails to capture the strength and resilience of the iconic character. Saif Ali Khan's performance as Ravana, though initially promising, falls victim to weak writing and fails to elevate the character beyond a one-dimensional villain.

The pacing of "Adipurush" is uneven, with certain scenes dragging on for too long while others feel rushed and underdeveloped. The lack of cohesive storytelling and the absence of emotional resonance make it difficult to stay engaged throughout the film's runtime.

In conclusion, "Adipurush" is a disappointing cinematic experience that fails to do justice to the epic Ramayan. The film's subpar visual effects, misguided interpretation of the source material, and lackluster performances contribute to its overall lack of impact. Fans of the Ramayan and those expecting a grand and faithful adaptation will find themselves sorely let down by this underwhelming rendition.

On the unusual decent rating of three stars out of five, i.e., six out of ten:

The film has been thrashed since the launch of the teaser, and I had given up completely on the movie. Countless negative reviews, memes, trolled trailers, and commentary on the poor dialogue and VFX---the stream of critique on the movie was endless. I just went in anticipating the worst thing. And when the movie was over, I felt it was not "that" bad. Gets an extra star just because I was sensitized to bad bits, and the good bits felt decent, so it ended up been an anticlimactic experience for me. Had I gone in blind, I would have rated it either one or two... the anticipation of absolute worst helped. Also the acceptance of the movie being a "loosely-adapted" film based on Ramayana---just another action flick---helped me to just relax and watch it without the burden of negative publicity. Don't do the folly of equating it to the Ramayana despite what the title, the moviemakers, or other people affiliated with the movie say---life will be much easier that way; otherwise, all you will see is endless flaws, and then even negative stars would be insufficient to rate the movie.

Coming to the movie:

Major things that did not work for me:

a) Prabhas: One-tone angry man look. It has been six years since Baahubali 2 released, and he is still caught in that Baahubali mold. Awful. All his T-series flicks, including Saaho and Radhe Shyam, have been horrendous. Perhaps it was the genius of Rajamouli and freshness of Prabhas to non-Telugu audiences that shined in the Baahubali duology.

B) Color grade of the film: Even in a 4k premiere theater with a 3D show, the entire film looks so dark. Many things are not visible at all, which might have been done to hide the many valid criticisms when the teaser was launched. No day shots or lack of light felt so off throughout the film.

C) Animation: There are several interesting, nice bits of VFX and animation in the film mixed with equally poor, low-quality, horrendous effects. The most notable of the poor animation shots being everything to do with the Vanar army (Lord Ram's army) and Lanka army (Ravana's army). The sequence of Bali and Sugriva fight was simply yuck. Several of the animation shots were simply unrefined and done without due attention to the detail. The intro scene of Lord Ram also felt shoddy (I was like what the heck are Dementors doing in the film 😂).

Major thing that worked for me:

a) Sound: The sound department did good (not talking about the music here). Perhaps it was the Atmos effect, or the choice of my seating to be in the dead center of the theatre, that the sound effects and design felt good throughout the movie.

B) Watching on a big screen in 3D. The scenes getting trolled everywhere did not look "that" bad in a big, good-quality theatre. Also some visual effects looked nice.

C) Once you accept that the film is "very" loosely based on the original text, I liked the dark, evil (and comical in parts) portrayal of Ravana and Lanka. Although I am sure that I am in a rare company here.

On Om Raut: I liked his Lokmanya Ek Yugpurush, and thought that Tanaji was okayish--sub-par at best unlike how much people enjoyed it. The difference in quality of the two films is fairly evident when you switch from a real movie like Lokmanya into the use of VFX and animation heavy film like Tanhaji. Tanhaji felt unreal, visually dark, and unrefined in the CGI domain. Alas it at least had some live action unlike Adipurush where they bit more than they could chew---everything looks so cartoonish. Very little feels live action, which is a major bane of the film.

On Manoj Muntashir Shukla: I did not give much attention to the dialogues, so no comments---although I can firmly say that at least the dialogues were not as awful as in Brahmastra 😂.

review_title: A Disastrous Disguise of the Epic: Adipurush Falls Flat on Its Face
review_detailed_main:
Adipurush, touted as an epic retelling of the Ramayana, turns out to be an absolute disappointment that utterly fails to capture the essence and grandeur of the ancient epic. From its cringe-worthy bat dialogs to its questionable casting choices and misrepresentations of the Ramayana, this film is a colossal letdown.

Let's start with the bat dialogs. It's mind-boggling how the filmmakers thought it would be a good idea to include such juvenile and ridiculous dialogues in a supposedly epic movie. The usage of modern slang and language completely undermines the authenticity and reverence that should have been accorded to the Ramayana. It feels like the writers were more interested in pandering to a younger audience rather than treating the source material with respect.

Next comes the casting, which is nothing short of a disaster. While Prabhas may be a popular actor, he is woefully miscast as Lord Rama. His portrayal lacks the depth, charisma, and regal aura that one would expect from the legendary character. The casting decision feels more like a marketing gimmick aimed at capitalizing on Prabhas' star power rather than a thoughtful choice to bring the character of Lord Rama to life.

The misrepresentation of the Ramayana is perhaps the most egregious offense committed by Adipurush. The filmmakers have taken significant liberties with the original story, distorting key elements and diluting its cultural and spiritual significance. The epic is a revered and cherished part of Indian heritage, and it deserved a faithful adaptation that respects its core values and teachings. Instead, Adipurush presents a watered-down version that does a disservice to the original text and its followers.

Moreover, the film fails to create a cohesive narrative and struggles to maintain a consistent tone. The pacing feels uneven, with unnecessary deviations and subplots that add nothing substantial to the overall story. This lack of focus undermines the emotional impact and fails to capture the epic scale and timeless appeal of the Ramayana.

In terms of visual effects and production design, Adipurush falls short of expectations as well. The CGI feels artificial and unconvincing, failing to create a seamless blend between the real and the mythical worlds. The film's set designs lack the grandeur and attention to detail that would have brought the ancient era to life. It feels like a missed opportunity to create a visually stunning and immersive experience.

All in all, Adipurush is a misfire on multiple fronts. Its bat dialogs, questionable casting choices, and misrepresentations of the Ramayana leave a bitter taste in the mouths of those who were eagerly anticipating a faithful and awe-inspiring retelling of the epic. It's a disservice to the rich cultural heritage it claims to represent and an example of how not to adapt a beloved story. Save your time and seek out other adaptations that do justice to the epic tale of the Ramayana.

review_title: Disappointing Departure from Sacred Texts and Mythological Figures
review_detailed_main:
Adipurush, a highly anticipated film based on sacred texts and books, had the potential to captivate audiences with its retelling of ancient tales. Unfortunately, the movie falls short in various aspects, deviating from the way life has been portrayed in these revered texts. The characters in Adipurush fail to do justice to the actual personalities of the holy figures they represent, leaving audiences feeling disconnected and disappointed.

One of the significant disappointments in Adipurush is the portrayal of Hanumanji. A character known for his charisma and wisdom, Hanumanji's portrayal lacks the captivating presence that is expected of him. The dialogues given to this iconic character are wasted, failing to convey the depth and essence of Hanumanji's wisdom and devotion. This missed opportunity to bring out the true charisma of Hanumanji is a major letdown for fans.

Another drawback of Adipurush lies in its language. The movie suffers from a lack of clarity in its dialogue delivery, with an excessive use of modern slangs that seem out of place in the ancient setting. This modernization of language undermines the authenticity of the film and creates a jarring contrast between the setting and the dialogue. It would have been more appropriate to use language that resonates with the historical period being depicted.

Moreover, the characters of Ram and Ravan, central figures in the epic tale, are portrayed in a manner that deviates significantly from their well-known personalities. The film fails to capture the essence of these characters, resulting in a lack of emotional connection between the audience and the protagonists. The portrayal of Ram and Ravan lacks the complexity and depth that make them such compelling figures in mythology.

Furthermore, Adipurush fails to evoke the feeling of a kingdom for either Ram or Ravan. The grandeur and magnificence that are synonymous with these characters' reigns are missing, leaving the audience without a true sense of the power and glory that they once possessed. The lack of attention to this crucial aspect detracts from the overall immersive experience of the film.

One of the most disappointing aspects of Adipurush is its excessive reliance on Western animation and models. Rather than creating a unique visual style that pays homage to the source material, the movie feels like a sluggish copy of some cheap Hollywood production. This over-adaptation of Western influences diminishes the originality and distinctiveness that could have been achieved, resulting in a lackluster cinematic experience.

In conclusion, Adipurush fails to live up to the expectations set by its source material. The movie's departure from the way life has been portrayed in sacred texts and books is a major letdown, leaving fans feeling disconnected. The characters in the film, including Hanumanji, lack the charisma and depth that they should possess, and the use of modern slangs in the dialogue further undermines the film's authenticity. Additionally, the portrayal of Ram and Ravan is inconsistent with their true personalities, and the film fails to evoke the grandeur and kingdom associated with these figures. The excessive adaptation of Western animation and models only adds to the disappointment, making Adipurush feel like a lackluster imitation of a cheap Hollywood movie. Overall, Adipurush falls short in its execution and fails to deliver a captivating cinematic experience.

The movie Adipurush, a parody of the epic Ramayana, attempts to incorporate its own imaginative elements inspired by Hollywood movies. However, this attempt has backfired, resulting in a disastrous outcome. The Ramayana is not merely a story from Hindu mythology, but a guide for individuals on how to live a good and respectful life. These teachings have been passed down through generations by our parents and grandparents.

The epic emphasizes the importance of responsibilities, with the husband being the head of the household and the wife managing the home. It also emphasizes the significance of young people following and respecting their elders. On the other side of the story, Ravana, the king of Lanka, is portrayed as a character who is not a demon but rather overconfident and possesses excessive self-respect. This overconfidence stems from his victories and his devotion to the gods. However, it leads him to become excessively greedy, believing he can do whatever he desires, including capturing and imprisoning women.

Ravana's character teaches us the dangers of becoming overconfident in our own success, as it can ultimately lead to a downfall from a high position to a low one. The movie also introduces creative elements such as Ravana forcefully stealing the sky chariot, Pushpaka Viman, from Kubera, which transforms into a demonic bat. However, these additions seem to be attempts to inject Hollywood-inspired imagination into the minds of the audience, but they are received poorly and result in a disaster.

I strongly object to this narrative of the great epic Ramayana being turned into a parody. The movie Adipurush fails to capture the essence of the original story and instead presents a distorted version that deviates from the valuable lessons and teachings it imparts.

Adipurush review :

Lord Ram in a perennial angry mode; Sita Mata lacking purity and innocence; Lord Hanuman indulging in Bombaiyya slang; The mighty Raavan without a crown or throne hammering away like an iron-smith in one scene; A bare chested Indrajeet with a tattoed body appearing a criss cross between Marvel's Quicksilver and DC's Flash.

Guys, is this a joke?

Is it a spoof?

Is it even a film?

Whatever it is, Adipurush is NOT Ramayana. It just can't be.

Making a blatant mockery of the great religious epic, this film showcases the worst side of today's Bollywood, which has become creatively bankrupt in recent times.

I had loved Om Raut's Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior (2020) and naturally, was eagerly awaiting his interpretation of Ramayan. But Adipurush was a painful watch. It truly saddens and pains you to view the substandard execution on all aspects from VFX to dialogues to those jarring animated demons jumping on your face in 3D. The dark colour pallette given to the supposedly glittering 'Sone Ki Lanka' makes you wonder if this Raavan is inhabiting some other universe here. Asgard, probably!!

The only saving grace (if you can call it that) is Ajay Atul's scintillating score with 'Jai Shri Ram' chants elevating the proceedings to a reasonable extent.

Prabhas, a brilliant actor no doubt, reprises his Bahubali act while playing Lord Ram. The serene and calm composure associated with the God is missing. Not his fault, the script offers no scope. Kriti Sanon is beautiful but lacks the purity and sanctity of Mata Sita. You can say Saif has performed well if his character was Alauddin Khilji and not Raavan. Devdatta Nage, another fantastic actor, is made to play Lord Hanuman mouthing lines like 'Tere baap ki..'. Oh please!! Sunny Singh is turned in to an extra as Laxman. And pray, what was the need to show Vibhishan's wife (Trupti Toradmal) with all that cleavage sheavage? Who even thought of this scene, man!!

I can go on ranting but honestly, that will be an exercise in futility. Bollywood ka 'funda' is crystal clear, nowadays. Just rake in the moolah within the first weekend and then sell the movie on OTT to garner the profits and move on. Creativity or aesthetics be damned!!

Adipurush may become a box office hit if I go by the 'Housefull' crowd at Citylight Cinema, Matunga where I saw it last evening. But does that really matter?!! Ramanand Sagar's TV series Ramayan (1987) is still remembered and revered after three decades. Adipurush will be forgotten by next friday. Or is it already??!!!

Regards, Sumeet Nadkarni.

review_detailed_main:
"Adipurush," the new Indian mythological action-fantasy film, presents a familiar tale with a star-studded cast, including Prabhas in the lead role. The movie's ambition to adapt elements from The Ramayana while bringing larger-than-life Hindu gods and epic battles to the screen is evident. However, it struggles to rise above its visual shortcomings, particularly its subpar and distractingly artificial special effects.

The narrative revolves around the courageous hero Raghava (Prabhas), also known as Ram, who sets out to rescue his kidnapped wife Sita (Kriti Sanon) from the clutches of the evil multi-headed god Lankesh/Ravana (Saif Ali Khan). The film's title, "Adipurush," meaning "First Man" in Sanskrit, hints at its mythological themes and the grandeur it aspires to achieve.

Unfortunately, the film's visual effects undermine its potential greatness. The amateurish and unconvincing computer-generated imagery detracts from the immersive experience, making the first part of the film feel tedious and uninspiring. Despite the high budget, the shoddy green-screen compositing and poorly-rendered elements overshadow the otherwise captivating narrative.

Prabhas' charismatic presence and his initial confrontation with demonic wraiths offer moments of excitement, but the film's technical shortcomings become increasingly evident as the story unfolds. The scenes involving Sita and Raghava's romantic moments encircled by poorly-executed pink flamingos exemplify the film's struggle to create a believable world.

Additionally, the musical numbers, particularly those involving Sita and Lankesh, suffer from lackluster visuals and fail to generate the desired emotional impact. The film's poetic song lyrics and expository dialogue often come across as forced and contrived. The characters' movements often serve to highlight the deficiencies of the computer-generated graphics, diminishing the overall quality of the film.

Despite its derivative nature, borrowing elements from popular series like "Game of Thrones" and "Lord of the Rings," as well as the "Baahubali" films, "Adipurush" manages to salvage some dramatic tension in its concluding battles. The showdown between Raghava, his brother Sesh/Laxmana, and the formidable Lankesh and his second-in-command Indrajit provides a narrow focus that delivers sporadic moments of engagement.

Director Om Raut, known for his work on "Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior," attempts to infuse the film with grandeur, particularly in its climactic battle scenes. Yet, even as the film gradually escalates towards its finale, the subpar visual effects persist, inhibiting the realization of its full potential.

In the end, "Adipurush" grapples with the paradox of aiming for epic proportions while being hindered by its own technical limitations. While the film's cast and its ambitious narrative offer glimpses of promise, its glaring visual flaws and lack of visual finesse ultimately prevent it from achieving the grand cinematic spectacle it aspires to be. I would rate the film a 5/10 due to its disappointing visual execution and missed opportunities to create a truly immersive mythological experience.

review_detailed_main:
"Adipurush" is a film based on "The Ramayana" attributed to Valmiki. It is a holy text, a saga revered by Hindus and Buddhists alike. And, apparently, the film offended many of these people...much like a poor depiction of Muhammad or Jesus would offend many.

Unfortunately, I am NOT a Hindu or Buddhist and my knowledge of "The Ramayana" is poor (good for an American...but that says little). So, the parts that offend many are parts of the film I might not even notice. Also, because I am from a different cultural and religious background, I might somehow misinterpret or misunderstand some parts of the movie...and I apologize in advance for this.

The story is about Rama and was first written down 27-28 centuries ago. In the saga, Ram is sent into exile for 14 years...taking his wife and brother with him. During this time, they have many adventures, battle demons and much more. However, what happened to Ram BEFORE the exile and much of the context for the story appears to be missing.

The first thing I noticed about the film was how horrible the CGI was in the movie...and there is a LOT of CGI. Many of the scenes honestly look like PS2 or PS3 cut scenes...scenes made 15-20 years ago instead of in 2023 like this film. A couple striking examples occur early in the movie. In one, two actors are clumsily superimposed into a mountain top snow scene. In another, demons attack Ram and it looks just horrid....as if some untalented student did the CGI. So, apart from religious problems, the film just looks terrible and having real live non-CGI actors and practical effects might have cost more...but it would have looked so much better.

By comparison, I saw "Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within" about a week ago and its CGI was better and often more realistic than "Adipurush"...and the Final Fantasy movie debute in 2001!!!

So what DID I like about the film? Well, the music was appropriately epic and pretty amazing (hence it earns a 2 instead of 1). Otherwise, I noticed nothing good about the movie whatsoever. I think I'd have been better off just reading "The Ramayana" or at least a Wikipedia summary of it.

review_title: A Devastating Departure from the Epic
review_detailed_main:
Adipurush, a highly anticipated 3D movie adaptation of the revered Indian epic Ramayana, falls short of expectations and fails to do justice to the beloved story. The film starts with a promising rendition of the Ram Siya Ram song, accompanied by beautiful illustrations. However, the movie quickly devolves into a disgraceful portrayal of the epic narrative.

The cast's performances come across as forced, with Kriti lacking the motherly aura of Sita Mata and Prabhas seemingly trapped in his Bahubali phase. Saif Ali Khan's portrayal of Ravan is criticized for resembling a character from a DJ concert rather than a formidable antagonist.

Several aspects of the movie are deeply disturbing. The language used in the dialogues, such as Hanumanji's disrespectful lines, feels offensive towards a revered deity. The film takes liberties with the story, introducing inaccurate and exaggerated elements, such as Ravana's anaconda massage and the depiction of him feeding meat to the bat (which on the first place is a question marks because apparently Pushpak Viman is replaced by a creepy bat) which contradicts his Brahmin background.

Furthermore, the movie includes a random erotic scene, where an unknown woman is shown along with Vibhishan, and subsequently, the woman is shown changing clothes while Vibhishan is present nearby. This scene seems unnecessary and out of place in a narrative centered on a revered epic.

Overall, Adipurush fails to maintain emotional connection with the audience and strays far from the original story of Ramayana. Its poor writing, lack of authenticity, and departure from the essence of the epic are notable drawbacks. The only redeeming aspect is the music composed by Ajay Atul, which receives praise for its quality.

Considering the movie's shortcomings and offensive content, it is not recommended to spend time and money on watching Adipurush in theaters. The film's attempts at modernizing the epic story result in a disrespectful portrayal that may disappoint and alienate audiences who hold Ramayana dear.

Title: Adipurush: A Magnificent Epic That Transcends Boundaries

My rating :10/10

Adipurush, the highly anticipated Indian epic fantasy film directed by Om Raut, is a visual extravaganza that brings the ancient tale of the Ramayana to life on the big screen. With its grand scale, breathtaking visuals, and powerful performances, Adipurush succeeds in capturing the essence of the timeless mythological narrative.

The film revolves around the legendary characters of Lord Rama and the demon king Ravana, played brilliantly by Prabhas and Saif Ali Khan, respectively. Prabhas delivers a captivating performance as Lord Rama, exuding grace, valor, and righteousness. His portrayal is both stoic and emotive, allowing audiences to connect with his character on a deeper level. Saif Ali Khan, on the other hand, brings a charismatic and menacing presence to the role of Ravana, showcasing his versatility as an actor.

One of the standout aspects of Adipurush is its awe-inspiring visual effects. The movie boasts stunning cinematography and meticulous attention to detail in every frame. The larger-than-life sets, breathtaking landscapes, and intricate costumes transport viewers to a mythical world filled with gods, demons, and epic battles. The action sequences are choreographed with finesse, and the use of CGI is seamless, enhancing the overall cinematic experience.

Om Raut's direction is commendable, as he skillfully balances the grandeur of the story with intimate character moments. He manages to present the conflict between good and evil with depth and nuance, allowing for a multi-dimensional exploration of the characters' motivations and dilemmas. The screenplay, written by Prakash Kapadia, masterfully adapts the Ramayana into a contemporary narrative that resonates with audiences of all backgrounds.

The supporting cast, including Kriti Sanon as Sita and Sunny Singh as Lakshmana, deliver commendable performances, adding depth to the story and complementing the lead actors effectively. Their chemistry and camaraderie contribute to the emotional core of the film.

While Adipurush is an enthralling cinematic experience, there are a few minor flaws that prevent it from achieving perfection. At times, the pacing feels slightly uneven, with certain scenes dragging on longer than necessary. Additionally, some character arcs could have been further developed to provide a more well-rounded narrative.

Despite these minor shortcomings, Adipurush is an extraordinary achievement in Indian cinema. It is a testament to the immense talent and dedication of the cast and crew involved. The film's powerful storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and stellar performances make it a must-watch for fans of epic fantasies and lovers of mythological tales.

Overall, Adipurush transports the audience into a mythical realm, where gods and demons clash in a battle that transcends time. It is a cinematic spectacle that celebrates the age-old tale of good versus evil while leaving a lasting impact on the viewer.

review_title: A lazy version of Ramayana critiqued by a Hindu (closet athiest)
review_detailed_main:
I am a Hindu who grew up in India. Most people know about Ramayana thanks to an epic serial made in late 80s by Ramanand Sagar. Additionally, Ramayana is part of lots of people growing up in North India thanks to Ramleela. Ramleela is street theater that takes place a week before Dusherra (20 days before diwali) on street corners everywhere in North India. Ramleela depicts the story of Ramayana and each production takes their take depending on their budget and talent. I say this because I don't have any problem with producer Om Raut making their own artistic version. My problem is that his version is a lazy version where artistic liberties are taken and replaced with heavy dose of plagiarism or plain thoughtlessness.

Let's start with dialogues. In the guise of being modern and relevant we have some really thoughtless words uttered by characters who would never speak in that manner.

Editing and pacing of movie is slow and almost makes you go to sleep. There are just way too many slow motion shots and there is absolutely nothing natural about what you see.

CGI is used extensively in this movie but unfortunately it is of very poor quality. You feel like you are watching and animation movie at all times.

Lot of side characters are just lifted from western movies. Vanar Sena (Monkey army) looks like is lifted directly from planet of Apes. Ravana is desired to be shown bigger than others and that makes him looks he is floating and look they are trying to copy Thanos with a buzz cut. Asuras in lanka looks to be lifted directly from Orcs in Lord of the rings. Lanka is a direct copy of Asgard from Thor. Ravana looks to be riding the dragon from Game of Thrones.

Thoughfulness and artistry is lacking and it instead is replaced by borrowed CGI and whole lot of nothing. Even though I am not religious it looks this was a huge waste of money and opportunity.

How could someone be so wrong about Ramayan??? I'm just shocked and kinda angry. I mean why did Om Raut make such a blunder out of a very basic story. I wish I could give it -10. It is absolutely pathetic how they ruined an epic just like it's no big deal. Serious lack of conviction is aptly visible in this doomed project.

I couldn't believe why they would release such kind of a product. If the young minds of today get their understanding of Valmiki Ramayana from this movie then I don't know what will happen in near future.

If this will be their Raavan then i don't know what exactly will they think of Ramayana in the first place. Absolutely lack luster VFX isn't the only problem with this film. Rather VFX is much less of a problem in this movie. The main flaw is in this representation that has been made by the makers. Raavan has an attire of an islamic dictator. He has been shown wearing a t-shirt along with leather straps over him with a spiky hairstyle and rather non-sense get up. He is shown riding a bat but there is no mention of why he is riding a bat, is that pushpak vimaan or what. Characters around him are just goofy men or rather cartoons in his army who behave like lord of the rings character. Indrajit is shown as a guy having powers of Flash and attire of Connor McGregor. I can't imagine this being Ramayana.

The first point of Introduction of Rama is pathetic. Shree Ram is shown as fighting some random CGI demons. Who are they? Why are they attacking Sita? Nothing is told as if it's a cartoon film. Even with such a story like that of Ramayana, Raavana's motivations are so childish and vague that we still don't know what he wants. We are shown a scene worth of 2 mins where Ravana's sister gets her nose cut by Laxman's arrow. That scene is so childish. Every detail about Rama's vanvaas is shown to us in a 3 minutes introduction. The movie doesn't want you to connect with any character. The most connected I was to a character was Jatayu which was just for a 3 minutes CGI sequence. Still I was more connected to it than Sita maa, Shree Ram or any one else.

Even walking Saif Ali khan is shown to us with CGI. As if his head is floating on a computer generated body leave alone the 10 head animation. Shree Ram's character is shown very much like a robot which is programmed to react in a certain way. I refuse to even think of this movie as Ramayana and any of the characters as the one in Ramayana.

In the end Ravan is killed by Rama but how did Rama know about shooting an arrow in his belly? Why didn't Ravan confronted Rama after this? A whole CGI climax of 30 minutes in a movie of 3 hours where the main essence of the story is skipped which doesn't allow you to connect with any character properly is the fundamental wrong with this film.

Dialogues are pathetic. They are using slang language in their conversations. At one point they talk in Shudhh Hindi at other point they just start talking in slangs. Hanuman ji uses phrases like "jalegi tere baap ki", "Lanka laga denge" and is being told that "ye teri bua ka bageecha hai ki tu tehelne aa gaya". These dialogues are just the tip of the iceberg. A dialogue by Indrajit goes as "mere ek sapola ne tere shesh naag ko lamba kardiya". Now if you don't think this was intentional then I don't know what shows their intention.

Overall this movie is an unbearable garbage which no devotee of Shree Rama or any person in general deserves to witness and at least not by spending money. Don't watch it.
